description.raw:
* enable MATLAB building on Linux
 * find `mex` instead of just `mex.bat`
 * customize `mex` args for Linux vs. Windows
 * put Octave and MATLAB .mex files into separate directories (both build and install)
 * add custom `mexopts.sh` file to allow customization of compiler flags

This works for me on Trusty, at least as far as running `hx_matlab_controller.m`.

I haven't tried it on Windows, but I don't think that I've broken that support (except maybe for the change of .mex install location; I'm not sure how the SDK gets produced).

Note: I first was getting this error:

~~~~
>> hx_read_sensors
Invalid MEX-file '/home/gerkey/code/haptix/install/lib/x86_64-linux-gnu/haptix-comm/matlab/hxgz.mexa64':
/usr/local/MATLAB/R2014b/bin/glnxa64/../../sys/os/glnxa64/libstdc++.so.6: version `GLIBCXX_3.4.19' not found (required by
/home/gerkey/code/haptix/install/lib/x86_64-linux-gnu/libhaptix-comm.so.0)

Error in hx_read_sensors (line 27)
  sensor = hxgz('read_sensors');
~~~~

The issue seems to be caused by the copy of `libstdc++.so` that ships with MATLAB.  After finding it recommended for working around similar problems with other tools (e.g., openoffice), I did the following:

~~~~
cd /usr/local/MATLAB/R2014b/sys/os/glnxa64
sudo mv libstdc++.so.6 libstdc++.so.6.orig
~~~~

Effectively, that hides MATLAB's own c++ lib, which makes it use the system-installed one, which doesn't have the dependency problem.

This issue might be related to the fact that I'm building with gcc-4.8 (default on Trusty), and MATLAB only officially supports up through gcc-4.7 (you get a warning while building). Then again, I installed gcc-4.7 and built the .mex with it, and still got the same result.
